docs.title: Dobrodošli u Radioamaterski Priručnik
docs.text: Ovo je centralno mjesto za sve informacije o radioamaterizmu. Bilo da ste početnik koji želi položiti ispit ili iskusni operator koji traži specifične tehničke informacije, ovdje ćete pronaći sve što vam treba.

docs.title: Što je radioamaterizam?
docs.text: Radioamaterizam je hobi koji spaja ljude diljem svijeta putem radio valova. To je tehnički hobi koji uključuje konstruiranje, eksperimentiranje i komunikaciju.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• Propisi i Dozvole: Kako postati radioamater, zakoni i pravilnici.
  • Tehnika: Sve o elektronici, antenama i uređajima.
  • Rad na opsegu: Kako održati vezu, modovi rada i pravila.
  • CB Radio: Građanski opseg (Citizens Band).
  • Aktivnosti: Natjecanja, SOTA, DXing.
  • Krizne situacije: Uloga radioamatera u hitnim situacijama.
  • Zajednica: Klubovi i udruge.
  • Resursi: Linkovi i alati.

Novosti

Stranica je u izradi! Pratite nas za nove sadržaje.

docs.title: Aktivnosti
docs.text: Radioamaterizam nudi mnoštvo aktivnosti.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• Natjecanja (Contesting): Borba za što veći broj veza.
  • DX rad: Veze s dalekim i rijetkim zemljama.
  • Rad u pokretu: SOTA (planine), POTA (parkovi), IOTA (otoci).
  • Sateliti: Komunikacija preko amaterskih satelita.
  • ARG: Amaterska radiogoniometrija ("lov na lisice").

docs.title: Amaterska radiogoniometrija (ARG)
docs.text: Poznato i kao "Lov na lisice" (Fox Hunting).

docs.title: Što je ARG?
docs.text: Tehničko-sportska disciplina gdje natjecatelji pomoću prijemnika i antene traže skrivene odašiljače ("lisice") u prirodi.

docs.title: Kategorije
docs.text:
• 3.5 MHz (80m): Klasična disciplina. Prijemnici su jednostavniji.
  • 144 MHz (2m): Zahtjevnija disciplina zbog refleksija signala.

docs.title: Oprema
docs.text:
• Prijemnik: Posebno dizajniran za ARG, s usmjerenom antenom (feritna za 80m, Yagi/HB9CV za 2m).
  • Kompas i karta: Za orijentaciju u prirodi.

ARG je odličan način za učenje o propagaciji valova i boravak u prirodi. Hrvatska reprezentacija je jedna od najuspješnijih na svijetu!

docs.title: Natjecanja (Contesting)
docs.text: Radioamaterska natjecanja su "sportski" dio hobija. Cilj je održati što više veza u određenom vremenu.

docs.title: Kako to izgleda?
docs.text:
• Trajanje: Od nekoliko sati do 48 sati.
  • Razmjena: Umjesto dugih razgovora, razmjenjuje se samo raport (59) i serijski broj veze (ili zona, lokator).
  • Kategorije: Jedan operator (Single Op), Više operatora (Multi Op), Mala snaga (QRP), itd.

docs.title: Popularna natjecanja
docs.text:
• CQ WW DX: Najveće svjetsko natjecanje (listopad SSB, studeni CW).
  • 9A CW Contest: Hrvatsko natjecanje (prosinac).
  • IOTA Contest: Veze s otocima (srpanj).

docs.title: Oprema i softver
docs.text:
• Za ozbiljan rezultat potrebne su dobre antene i pojačala.
  • Koristi se specijalizirani softver (N1MM, DXLog) koji je povezan s radiom i automatski šalje telegrafiju ili glasovne poruke.

docs.title: DXing (Rad na daljinu)
docs.text: DXing je lov na daleke i rijetke zemlje (entitete).

docs.title: Što je DX?
docs.text:
• Na kratkom valu (HF), DX je obično veza s drugim kontinentom.
  • Na UKV-u (VHF/UHF), DX može biti i veza od nekoliko stotina kilometara.

docs.title: DXCC Lista
docs.text: ARRL vodi listu "DXCC entiteta". To nisu uvijek države; to mogu biti i udaljeni otoci (npr. Havaji, Antarktika). Trenutno ih ima oko 340. Cilj svakog DX-era je potvrditi veze sa svih 340 entiteta.

docs.title: Kako uhvatiti DX?
docs.text:
1. Slušanje: 90% DXinga je slušanje.
  2. DX Cluster: Web stranice gdje drugi objavljuju koga čuju (npr. DX Summit).
  3. Pile-up: Situacija kad stotine stanica zove jednu rijetku DX stanicu. Potrebna je vještina i strpljenje da se probijete.
  4. Split rad: DX stanica sluša na jednoj frekvenciji, a odašilje na drugoj (npr. "UP 5"). Nikad ne zovite na frekvenciji DX stanice ako radi split!

docs.title: Rad u pokretu (Portable)
docs.text: Izlazak u prirodu s radiostanicom je jedan od najljepših dijelova hobija.

docs.title: SOTA (Summits On The Air)
docs.text: Program koji potiče radioamatere na rad s planinskih vrhova. - Aktivator: Penje se na vrh i uspostavlja veze (mora nositi svu opremu). - Lovac: Skuplja bodove radeći veze s aktivatorima. - SOTA Website

docs.title: POTA (Parks On The Air)
docs.text: Slično kao SOTA, ali se radi iz nacionalnih parkova i parkova prirode. - Pristupačnije jer se često može doći autom blizu lokacije. - POTA Website

docs.title: IOTA (Islands On The Air)
docs.text: Rad s otoka. - Vrlo popularno, posebno ljeti. - Neki otoci su rijetki i traženi (npr. Palagruža). - IOTA Website

docs.title: Oprema za portable
docs.text:
• Lagani uređaji (QRP, npr. Yaesu FT-818, Elecraft KX2).
  • Žičane antene (Dipol, End-fed) ili vertikalke na štapu za pecanje.
  • Baterijsko napajanje (LiFePO4).

docs.title: Satelitske komunikacije
docs.text: Radioamateri imaju svoje satelite u orbiti!

docs.title: Kako to radi?
docs.text: Većina amaterskih satelita su "leteći repetitori". - Uplink: Frekvencija na kojoj šaljete signal (npr. 435 MHz). - Downlink: Frekvencija na kojoj slušate satelit (npr. 145 MHz). - Ovo se zove Mode U/V (UHF gore, VHF dolje).

docs.title: Dopplerov efekt
docs.text: Zbog velike brzine satelita, frekvencija se mijenja kako satelit dolazi i odlazi. Morate stalno korigirati frekvenciju na prijemu.

docs.title: Oprema
docs.text:
• Za FM satelite (npr. ISS, SO-50) dovoljna je ručna stanica i mala usmjerena antena (Yagi) koju držite u ruci.
  • Za linearne satelite (SSB/CW) potrebna je bolja oprema i antene s rotacijom (azimut/elevacija).

docs.title: ISS (Međunarodna svemirska postaja)
docs.text: Na ISS-u se često nalaze astronauti koji su radioamateri. Ponekad se javljaju školama (ARISS program) ili šalju SSTV slike.

docs.title: CB Radio (Citizens Band)
docs.text: Građanski opseg (CB) je javno dostupna radio usluga koja ne zahtijeva polaganje stručnog ispita, ali ima svoja pravila.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• Uvod u CB: Povijest i namjena.
  • Propisi i kanali: Dozvoljene frekvencije (27 MHz) i snage.
  • Oprema: Stanice, antene i pribor.

docs.title: Tablica Kanala
docs.text: CB koristi 40 kanala u području 27 MHz. Najpopularniji kanal za pozivanje je kanal 9 (hitni slučajevi) i kanal 19 (kamiondžije/cesta).

docs.title: Propisi i Kanali
docs.text: Iako nema ispita, postoje pravila koja se moraju poštivati.

docs.title: Dozvoljeni parametri (Hrvatska / EU)
docs.text:
• Frekvencijski opseg: 26.965 MHz - 27.405 MHz.
  • Modulacija: AM, FM, SSB (LSB/USB).
  • Snaga: 4W (AM/FM), 12W (SSB).

docs.title: Tablica Kanala
docs.text:
Kanal Frekvencija (MHz) Namjena 1 26.965 9 27.065 Hitni kanal (Emergency) 19 27.185 Cesta / Kamiondžije 20 27.205 30 27.305 40 27.405

Napomena: Postoje i "međukanali" (Alpha kanali) koji se preskaču u standardnom rasporedu.

docs.title: CB Oprema
docs.text: Oprema za CB je jednostavnija i jeftinija od radioamaterske.

docs.title: Radio stanice
docs.text:
• Mobilne: Najčešće. Ugrađuju se u auto ili koriste kao bazne uz ispravljač. (npr. President, Midland, Albrecht).
  • Ručne: Manji domet, ali praktične.

docs.title: Antene
docs.text: Ključ dometa na 27 MHz (valna duljina 11m). - Mobilne antene: Skraćene zavojnicom. Što duža, to bolja (od 1m do 2m). Često se montiraju na magnet. - Bazne antene: Velike vertikalke (5-7 metara). Omogućuju domete od 20-50 km lokalno, a stotine km kad su uvjeti propagacije dobri (DX).

docs.title: SWR
docs.text: Kao i kod radioamatera, antena mora biti ugođena (SWR < 1.5). Većina CB antena ima vijak za podešavanje duljine.

docs.title: Uvod u CB (Citizens Band)
docs.text: CB (Građanski opseg) je "radio za narod". Za razliku od radioamaterizma, ne zahtijeva polaganje ispita.

docs.title: Povijest
docs.text: Nastao u SAD-u 1940-ih, CB je doživio procvat 1970-ih ("Konvoj", "Smokey and the Bandit"). U Europi i Hrvatskoj popularan je među vozačima kamiona, off-road entuzijastima i ljudima koji žele besplatnu komunikaciju na kratke udaljenosti.

docs.title: Razlika od radioamaterizma
docs.text:
• Nema ispita: Svatko može kupiti uređaj i koristiti ga.
  • Ograničena snaga: Obično 4W (AM/FM) ili 12W (SSB).
  • Fiksni kanali: Koristi se 40 kanala, nema slobodnog biranja frekvencije (VFO).
  • Namjena: Osobna i poslovna komunikacija, zabava.

docs.title: Tko koristi CB danas?
docs.text:
• Vozači kamiona: Za informacije o prometu (Kanal 19).
  • Off-road klubovi: Komunikacija u koloni.
  • Prepperi: Komunikacija u slučaju katastrofe.

docs.title: Zajednica
docs.text: Radioamaterizam je društveni hobi.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• HRS: Hrvatski radioamaterski savez.
  • Radioklubovi: Pronađite klub u svojoj blizini.
  • YOTA: Mladi u radioamaterizmu.

docs.title: Savezi i organizacije
docs.text: Radioamateri su organizirani na nacionalnoj i međunarodnoj razini.

docs.title: HRS (Hrvatski radioamaterski savez)
docs.text: Krovna organizacija radioamatera u Republici Hrvatskoj. - Članstvo: Članom se postaje preko radiokluba ili direktno. - QSL Biro: HRS vodi nacionalni QSL biro za razmjenu kartica. - Ispiti: Organizira polaganje ispita. - Natjecanja: Organizira 9A CW, 9A Activity i druga natjecanja. - Web stranica HRS-a

docs.title: IARU (International Amateur Radio Union)
docs.text: Svjetska organizacija koja zastupa radioamatere pred ITU-om. - Hrvatska je članica IARU Regije 1. - Web stranica IARU

docs.title: Radioklubovi
docs.text: Radioklub je osnovna ćelija radioamaterizma. To je mjesto gdje se okupljaju entuzijasti, razmjenjuju iskustva i koriste zajedničku opremu.

docs.title: Zašto se učlaniti?
docs.text:
• Oprema: Klubovi često imaju vrhunske uređaje i antene koje si pojedinac teško može priuštiti.
  • Edukacija: Stariji članovi (mentori) prenose znanje novima.
  • Druženje: Radioamaterizam je društveni hobi.

docs.title: Kako pronaći klub?
docs.text:
Na stranicama HRS-a postoji popis svih aktivnih radioklubova u Hrvatskoj. - Popis radioklubova

Posjetite klub u svom gradu, upoznajte ljude i vidite kako to izgleda uživo!

docs.title: YOTA (Youngsters On The Air)
docs.text: YOTA je međunarodna inicijativa IARU Regije 1 s ciljem privlačenja i zadržavanja mladih u radioamaterizmu.

docs.title: Aktivnosti
docs.text:
• YOTA Ljetni kampovi: Svake godine u drugoj zemlji, okupljaju stotine mladih radioamatera.
  • YOTA Mjesec (Prosinac): Posebne pozivne oznake sa sufiksom YOTA aktivne su cijeli mjesec. Cilj je održati vezu s njima.
  • YOTA Contest: Natjecanje prilagođeno mladima.

docs.title: YOTA Croatia
docs.text:
Hrvatska je vrlo aktivna u YOTA programu. Mladi hrvatski radioamateri redovito sudjeluju na kampovima i ostvaruju vrhunske rezultate u natjecanjima.

Ako imaš manje od 26 godina, ovo je program za tebe!

docs.title: Krizne situacije (EmComm)
docs.text: Radioamateri su često zadnja linija obrane kada svi drugi sustavi komunikacije zakažu.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• RMZO: Radioamaterska mreža za opasnost.
  • Postupci: Kako se ponašati u hitnim slučajevima.
  • Winlink: Slanje e-maila preko radija.

docs.title: Postupci u hitnim slučajevima
docs.text: Kada se dogodi nesreća, disciplina je ključna.

docs.title: Zlatna pravila
docs.text:
1. Slušaj: Ne odašilji ako nisi pozvan ili nemaš hitnu informaciju.
  2. Kratko i jasno: Koristi fonetsku abecedu. Izbjegavaj žargon.
  3. Zapiši: Sve poruke moraju biti zapisane (vrijeme, pošiljatelj, sadržaj).

docs.title: Vrste poruka
docs.text:
• Mayday / SOS: Neposredna životna opasnost. Apsolutni prioritet.
  • Pan-Pan: Hitna situacija, ali nema neposredne opasnosti po život.
  • Securite: Sigurnosno upozorenje (npr. o vremenu).

docs.title: IARU Emergency Message
docs.text: Standardizirani format za slanje poruka koji osigurava da se ništa ne izgubi u prijenosu.

docs.title: RMZO (Radioamaterska mreža za opasnost)
docs.text: RMZO je sustav unutar Hrvatskog radioamaterskog saveza koji se aktivira u slučaju katastrofa.

docs.title: Organizacija
docs.text:
• Nacionalna razina: Koordinira HRS u suradnji s Ravnateljstvom civilne zaštite.
  • Lokalna razina: Radioklubovi i pojedinci koji se stavljaju na raspolaganje lokalnim stožerima.

docs.title: Aktivacija
docs.text: RMZO se aktivira na poziv nadležnih tijela (112) ili samoinicijativno u slučaju očitog prekida telekomunikacija.

docs.title: Frekvencije
docs.text:
• 3.675 MHz (80m): Glavna frekvencija za nacionalnu koordinaciju.
  • 145.500 MHz (2m): Lokalna simpleks frekvencija.
  • Repetitori: Koriste se lokalni repetitori koji imaju neovisno napajanje.

docs.title: Winlink
docs.text: Winlink je globalni sustav za slanje e-maila putem radija. Ključan je u EmComm-u jer omogućuje slanje detaljnih izvještaja, popisa i slika kada internet ne radi.

docs.title: Kako radi?
docs.text:
• Korisnik: Spaja računalo na radio (HF ili VHF).
  • Gateway (RMS): Radio stanica spojena na internet koja prima poruku.
  • CMS: Centralni serveri (u oblaku) koji prosljeđuju mail na obični internet.

docs.title: Prednosti
docs.text:
• Radi i bez lokalnog interneta (preko HF-a se spajate na gateway u drugoj zemlji).
  • Podržava privitke (slike, PDF).
  • Integriran s obrascima civilne zaštite (ICS forms).

docs.title: Oprema
docs.text:
• Računalo sa softverom (Winlink Express).
  • Radio uređaj.
  • Modem (TNC) ili softverski modem (VARA).

docs.title: Rad na opsegu
docs.text: Ovdje ćete naučiti kako zapravo održavati veze, koje frekvencije koristiti i koja pravila ponašanja vrijede u eteru.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• Frekvencijski planovi: Raspodjela frekvencija po opsezima.
  • Vrste rada (Modovi): Detaljan pregled analognih i digitalnih modova.
  • Procedura veze: Kako započeti i završiti vezu (QSO).
  • Q-kodovi i kratice: Jezik radioamatera.
  • Dnevnici veza i QSL kartice: Potvrda održanih veza.

docs.title: Frekvencijski planovi
docs.text:
Frekvencijski plan (Band Plan) je dogovor o korištenju dijelova amaterskih opsega za različite vrste rada. Poštivanje band plana je stvar radioamaterske etike i kulture.

Ovdje prikazujemo plan za IARU Regiju 1 (Europa), uz napomene za Regiju 2 (Sjeverna i Južna Amerika) gdje postoje značajne razlike.

docs.title: Dnevnici veza i QSL kartice
docs.text: Svaka održana veza treba biti zapisana. To je zakonska obaveza i dio tradicije.

docs.title: Dnevnik veza (Logbook)
docs.text: Dnevnik mora sadržavati: - Datum i vrijeme (UTC). - Pozivnu oznaku korespondenta. - Frekvenciju (ili band). - Vrstu rada (Mode). - Raport (RST).

docs.title: Papirnati vs. Elektronički
docs.text: Danas većina koristi računalne programe (loggere) kao što su N1MM, DXKeeper ili Ham Radio Deluxe. Oni automatski bilježe vrijeme i frekvenciju (ako su spojeni na uređaj).

docs.title: QSL Kartice
docs.text: QSL kartica je pismena potvrda veze. To je "konačna pristojnost" radioamatera. - Papirnate QSL: Šalju se direktno poštom ili (jeftinije) preko QSL biroa nacionalnog saveza (HRS). - Elektroničke QSL: - LoTW (Logbook of The World): ARRL-ov sustav. Službeno priznat za diplome (DXCC). - eQSL: Popularan, ali manje "služben". - ClubLog: Odličan za analizu i OQRS (Online QSL Request System).

docs.title: Vrste rada (Modovi)
docs.text: Radioamateri koriste različite načine prijenosa informacija. Modove dijelimo na analogne i digitalne, a unutar njih na glasovne i podatkovne.

docs.title: Glasovni (Voice)
docs.text:
• SSB (Single Sideband): Najpopularniji mod za DX (daleke) veze na HF-u.
  • FM (Frequency Modulation): Standard za lokalne veze na VHF/UHF-u.
  • AM (Amplitude Modulation): Povijesni mod, danas se rjeđe koristi.

docs.title: Podatkovni (Data)
docs.text:
• CW (Continuous Wave): Telegrafija, najefikasniji mod za slabe signale.
  • SSTV (Slow Scan TV): Prijenos statičnih slika.

docs.title: Glasovni (Voice)
docs.text:
• DMR (Digital Mobile Radio): Komercijalni standard prilagođen za amatere.
  • D-Star: Prvi digitalni mod razvijen baš za radioamatere (Icom).
  • C4FM (System Fusion): Yaesu standard.

docs.title: Podatkovni (Data)
docs.text:
• FT8 / FT4: Najpopularniji modovi za slabe signale danas.
  • RTTY (Radioteletype): Klasik za natjecanja.
  • PSK31: Popularan "chat" mod.
  • APRS: Sustav za praćenje pozicije i kratke poruke.
  • Packet Radio: Prijenos podataka u paketima (AX.25).

docs.title: Procedura veze (QSO)
docs.text: Održavanje veze ima svoja pravila kako bi komunikacija bila efikasna i razumljiva.

docs.title: Osnovni pojmovi
docs.text:
• CQ: Opći poziv ("Calling Any Station").
  • DE: Od (koristi se u CW-u ili digitalnim modovima).
  • K: Prelazim na prijem ("Over").
  • 73: Pozdrav ("Best Regards").

docs.title: Primjer veze (SSB)
docs.text:
1. Poziv: "CQ CQ CQ, ovo je 9A1AA, 9A1AA zove i sluša."
  2. Odgovor: "9A1AA, ovo je DL1BBB."
  3. Raport: "DL1BBB, dobar dan. Tvoj signal je 59 (pet-devet), ime je Ivan, lokator JN75. 9A1AA."
  4. Potvrda: "9A1AA, hvala Ivane. Tvoj signal je također 59, moje ime je Hans. 73!"
  5. Kraj: "Hvala Hans, 73 i čujemo se. DL1BBB de 9A1AA."

docs.title: RST Sustav
docs.text:
Raport se sastoji od 3 znamenke (za CW) ili 2 (za SSB): - R (Readability): Čitljivost (1-5). - S (Signal Strength): Jačina signala (1-9). - T (Tone): Kvaliteta tona (1-9, samo za CW).

Primjer: 599 (Savršen signal na telegrafiji).

docs.title: Q-Kodovi
docs.text: Q-kodovi su standardizirane kratice od tri slova koje počinju slovom Q. Izvorno su razvijene za telegrafiju kako bi ubrzale komunikaciju, ali se danas koriste i u govornim modovima.

docs.title: Često korišteni Q-kodovi
docs.text: Kod Pitanje Odgovor / Obavijest QRA Kako se zove vaša stanica? Ime moje stanice je... QRG Koja je moja točna frekvencija? Vaša točna frekvencija je ... kHz. QRL Jeste li zauzeti? Zauzet sam (molim ne ometajte). QRM Imate li smetnje od drugih stanica? Imam smetnje od drugih stanica (1-5). QRN Imate li atmosferske smetnje? Imam atmosferske smetnje (1-5). QRO Trebam li povećati snagu? Povećajte snagu. QRP Trebam li smanjiti snagu? Smanjite snagu. QRT Prekidate li rad? Prekidam rad. QRZ Tko me zove? Zove vas... (na ... kHz). QSB Da li moj signal varira (feding)? Vaš signal varira. QSL Možete li potvrditi prijem? Potvrđujem prijem. QSO Možete li komunicirati s...? Mogu komunicirati s... QSY Trebam li promijeniti frekvenciju? Promijenite frekvenciju na ... kHz. QTH Koja je vaša lokacija? Moja lokacija je...

docs.title: Svi Q-kodovi (Radioamaterski)
docs.text: Kod Značenje QRA Ime stanice / Adresa QRB Udaljenost između stanica QRC Tko plaća račun (komercijalno, rijetko u amaterizmu) QRD Kamo idete i odakle dolazite? QRE Kada očekujete dolazak? QRF Vraćate li se? QRG Točna frekvencija QRH Varira li moja frekvencija? QRI Ton signala (T u RST) QRJ Primate li me loše? QRK Čitljivost signala (R u RST) QRL Zauzeta frekvencija QRM Smetnje od drugih stanica QRN Atmosferske smetnje (šum) QRO Velika snaga QRP Mala snaga QRQ Šaljite brže QRR Jeste li spremni za automatski rad? QRRS SOS za radioamatere (rijetko se koristi) QRS Šaljite sporije QRT Prestanak rada QRU Imate li što za mene? QRV Spreman sam QRW Trebam li obavijestiti...? QRX Pričekajte trenutak QRY Koji sam po redu? QRZ Tko me zove? QSA Jačina signala (S u RST) QSB Feding (variranje signala) QSD Ključanje je neispravno (telegrafija) QSK Mogu li vas čuti između mojih znakova (Break-in)? QSL Potvrda prijema (kartica) QSM Trebam li ponoviti zadnju poruku? QSN Jeste li me čuli? QSO Veza (kontakt) QSP Možete li prenijeti poruku? QSQ Imate li liječnika? QSR Trebam li ponoviti poziv? QSS Koju radnu frekvenciju koristite? QST Opći poziv svim radioamaterima (poruka) QSU Trebam li slati na ovoj frekvenciji? QSV Trebam li slati seriju V (za ugađanje)? QSW Hoćete li slati na ovoj frekvenciji? QSX Slušate li na...? QSY Promjena frekvencije QSZ Trebam li slati svaku riječ dvaput? QTA Trebam li poništiti poruku? QTB Slažete li se s mojim brojanjem riječi? QTC Imate li poruke za slanje? QTH Lokacija (grad, lokator) QTR Točno vrijeme

docs.title: Propisi i Dozvole
docs.text: Ovdje možete pronaći sve informacije vezane uz zakonsku regulativu i postupak stjecanja radioamaterske dozvole.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• Kako postati radioamater?: Informacije o polaganju ispita za P i A razred.
  • Hrvatski propisi: Zakoni i pravilnici HAKOM-a i HRS-a.
  • Međunarodni propisi: CEPT i IARU preporuke.
  • Pozivne oznake: Struktura i dodjela pozivnih oznaka u RH.

docs.title: Korisni dokumenti
docs.text:
• Pravilnik o amaterskim radijskim komunikacijama (NN)
  • Ispitna pitanja za P razred (HRS)

docs.title: Pozivne oznake
docs.text: Pozivna oznaka (Call Sign) je jedinstveni identifikator radioamaterske postaje.

docs.title: Struktura oznake (Hrvatska)
docs.text:
Hrvatske oznake sastoje se od tri dijela:

  1. Prefiks: 9A (označava Hrvatsku).
  2. Broj: 1 - 9 (u prošlosti označavao regiju, danas nema strogo geografsko značenje, ali se često koristi: 1-Zagreb, 2-Dalmacija, 3-Istra/Primorje, 4-Slavonija...). 0 se koristi za posebne znakove.
  3. Sufiks: 1, 2 ili 3 slova.
    • 1 slovo: Klubovi s dugom tradicijom ili posebni znakovi (npr. 9A1A).
    • 2 slova: Standardne osobne oznake (npr. 9A2AA) ili klubovi.
    • 3 slova: Standardne osobne oznake (npr. 9A3AAA).

docs.title: Vrste oznaka
docs.text:
• Osobne oznake: Dodjeljuju se fizičkim osobama nakon položenog ispita.
  • Klubske oznake: Dodjeljuju se radioklubovima.
  • Posebne oznake: Za natjecanja, obljetnice ili ekspedicije (npr. 9A80Z, 9A0HQ).

docs.title: Identifikacija u radu
docs.text: Prilikom rada, radioamater mora redovito emitirati svoju pozivnu oznaku (na početku, kraju i svakih 10-15 minuta tijekom veze). Kada radite iz druge zemlje (CEPT), prefiks te zemlje stavljate ispred svoje oznake (npr. S5/9A1AA ako ste u Sloveniji). Kada radite u pokretu, dodajete sufiks /P (portable), /M (mobile) ili /MM (maritime mobile).

docs.title: Hrvatski propisi
docs.text: Radioamaterizam u Hrvatskoj reguliran je nizom zakona i pravilnika.

docs.title: 1. Zakon o elektroničkim komunikacijama
docs.text: Temeljni zakon koji uređuje uporabu radiofrekvencijskog spektra. - Link na zakon (Narodne novine)

docs.title: 2. Pravilnik o amaterskim radijskim komunikacijama
docs.text: Ovo je "biblija" za radioamatere. Definira: - Vrste dozvola i razrede. - Frekvencijska područja i snage. - Tehničke uvjete za postaje. - Način formiranja pozivnih oznaka. - Link na pravilnik (Narodne novine) (Napomena: Provjerite najnoviju verziju)

docs.title: 3. Nacionalna tablica namjene radiofrekvencijskog spektra
docs.text: Dokument koji određuje namjenu svakog dijela spektra u RH.

docs.title: Nadležna tijela
docs.text:
• HAKOM (Hrvatska regulatorna agencija za mrežne djelatnosti): Izdaje dozvole, dodjeljuje pozivne oznake i nadzire rad.
    • Web: www.hakom.hr
  • HRS (Hrvatski radioamaterski savez): Nacionalni savez koji zastupa interese radioamatera, organizira ispite i vodi QSL biro.
    • Web: www.hamradio.hr

docs.title: Kako postati radioamater?
docs.text: Put do radioamaterske dozvole vodi preko polaganja stručnog ispita. U Republici Hrvatskoj postoje dva razreda radioamatera: P (početnički) i A (napredni).

docs.title: P razred (Početnički)
docs.text: Ovo je ulazna točka u svijet radioamaterizma. - Prava: Rad na svim amaterskim frekvencijskim područjima, ali s ograničenom snagom (do 100W na KV, do 50W na UKV). - Ispit: Jednostavniji, fokusiran na osnove propisa, tehnike i operativnog rada. - Preporuka: Idealno za početnike koji žele brzo krenuti s radom.

docs.title: A razred (Napredni)
docs.text: Puni radioamaterski privilegiji. - Prava: Rad maksimalnom dozvoljenom snagom (do 1.5 kW u nekim slučajevima) i pristup svim međunarodnim privilegijama (CEPT HAREC). - Ispit: Opsežniji, uključuje dublje poznavanje elektronike i radiotehnike. - Preporuka: Za one koji žele iskoristiti puni potencijal hobija.

docs.title: Postupak polaganja ispita
docs.text:
1. Priprema:
    • Pronađite najbliži radioklub (Popis klubova). Klubovi često organiziraju tečajeve.
    • Preuzmite priručnike i pitanja s web stranice HRS-a.
  2. Prijava:
    • Ispiti se organiziraju u radioklubovima ili direktno u HRS-u.
  3. Ispit:
    • Sastoji se od pismenog dijela (test). Nema više praktičnog dijela (Morseov kod nije obavezan).

docs.title: Nakon ispita
docs.text:
Nakon uspješno položenog ispita dobivate Svjedodžbu o položenom ispitu. S njom podnosite zahtjev HAKOM-u za izdavanje Dozvole za uporabu RF spektra i dodjelu pozivne oznake.

Savjet

Najbolji način za učenje je uz mentora u radioklubu. Praktično iskustvo je neprocjenjivo!

docs.title: Međunarodni propisi
docs.text: Radioamaterizam je globalni hobi, stoga je međunarodna koordinacija ključna.

docs.title: ITU (International Telecommunication Union)
docs.text: Međunarodna telekomunikacijska unija je agencija UN-a koja koordinira korištenje radiofrekvencijskog spektra na globalnoj razini. - Radio Regulations (RR): Međunarodni pravilnik koji definira amatersku službu.

docs.title: IARU (International Amateur Radio Union)
docs.text: Međunarodna radioamaterska unija zastupa interese radioamatera pred ITU-om. - Podijeljena je na 3 regije: 1. Regija 1: Europa, Afrika, Bliski Istok, Sjeverna Azija. 2. Regija 2: Sjeverna i Južna Amerika. 3. Regija 3: Ostatak Azije, Australija, Oceanija.

docs.title: CEPT (European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations)
docs.text: Europska organizacija koja usklađuje propise. - Preporuka T/R 61-01: Omogućuje radioamaterima s CEPT licencom (u Hrvatskoj A razred) rad u drugim zemljama potpisnicama bez dodatne birokracije (do 3 mjeseca). - Preporuka T/R 61-02: Harmonizirani ispitni program (HAREC).

docs.title: Što to znači za vas?
docs.text: Ako položite A razred u Hrvatskoj, vaša dozvola je priznata u većini europskih zemalja (i mnogim drugima). Možete putovati i raditi s vašom stanicom koristeći prefiks zemlje u kojoj se nalazite (npr. DL/9A1AA).

docs.title: Resursi
docs.text: Korisni linkovi, alati i softver za radioamatere.

docs.title: Online Alati
docs.text:
• PSK Reporter: Karta aktivnosti digitalnih modova u stvarnom vremenu.
  • DX Summit: DX Cluster.
  • Reverse Beacon Network (RBN): Automatsko praćenje CW/RTTY signala.

docs.title: Hrvatska (HR) - Istaknuto
docs.text:
• Hrvatski Radioamaterski Savez (HRS): Krovna organizacija.
  • HAKOM: Regulatorna agencija.
  • OIV: Odašiljači i veze.

docs.title: IARU Regija 1 (Europa, Afrika, Bliski Istok)
docs.text:
• IARU Region 1: Službena stranica regije 1.
  • DARC: Njemački savez (odlični tehnički resursi).
  • RSGB: Britanski savez.

docs.title: IARU Regija 2 (Amerike)
docs.text:
• ARRL: Američki savez (najveća baza znanja).
  • RAC: Kanadski savez.

docs.title: IARU Regija 3 (Azija, Pacifik)
docs.text:
• JARL: Japanski savez.
  • WIA: Australski savez.

docs.title: Softver
docs.text:
• WSJT-X: Standard za FT8/FT4.
  • N1MM Logger+: Najpopularniji contest log.
  • Ham Radio Deluxe: Sve-u-jednom rješenje.

docs.title: Radioamaterski Rječnik (Kratice)
docs.text:
Ovdje možete pronaći objašnjenja najčešćih kratica koje koriste radioamateri.

A | B | C | D | E | F | G | H | I | L | M | O | P | Q | R | S | T | U | V | W | X | Y | Z

docs.title: A
docs.text:
• AF (Audio Frequency): Zvučna frekvencija. Raspon frekvencija koje ljudsko uho može čuti (približno 20 Hz do 20 kHz).
  • AGC (Automatic Gain Control): Automatska regulacija pojačanja. Sklop koji održava konstantnu razinu izlaznog signala unatoč promjenama ulaznog signala.
  • ALC (Automatic Level Control): Automatska kontrola razine. Sklop u odašiljaču koji sprječava premodulaciju ili preopterećenje izlaznog stupnja.
  • AM (Amplitude Modulation): Amplitudna modulacija. Vrsta modulacije gdje se informacija prenosi promjenom amplitude nosioca.
  • APRS (Automatic Packet Reporting System): APRS (Link na EN). Sustav za prijenos podataka u stvarnom vremenu (pozicija, poruke, telemetrija) putem radija.

docs.title: B
docs.text:
• BCI (Broadcast Interference): Smetnje uzrokovane radiodifuznim postajama (npr. FM radio ili TV).
  • BFO (Beat Frequency Oscillator): BFO (Link na EN). Oscilator u prijemniku koji miješanjem s međufrekvencijom proizvodi čujan ton, nužan za prijem CW i SSB signala.
  • BK (Break-in): QSK (Link na EN). Mogućnost slušanja između vlastitih znakova tijekom odašiljanja telegrafije (Full Break-in).

docs.title: C
docs.text:
• CEPT: CEPT. Europska konferencija poštanskih i telekomunikacijskih uprava koja regulira međusobno priznavanje radioamaterskih dozvola.
  • CQ: CQ (poziv) (Link na EN). Opći poziv svim stanicama ("Calling any station").
  • CW (Continuous Wave): Telegrafija. Način komunikacije prekidanjem nosioca (Morseov kod).

docs.title: D
docs.text:
• dB (Decibel): Decibel. Logaritamska mjerna jedinica za izražavanje odnosa dviju veličina (npr. snage ili napona).
  • Dipol: Dipol antena. Najosnovnija vrsta antene koja se sastoji od dva vodiča, ukupne duljine približno pola valne duljine.
  • Dummy Load: Umjetno opterećenje (Link na EN). Otpornik (obično 50 ohma) koji se spaja na odašiljač umjesto antene za potrebe testiranja bez zračenja signala.
  • DX (Distance): DXing. Oznaka za veliku udaljenost ili vezu s udaljenom/rijetkom stanicom.

docs.title: E
docs.text:
• EME (Earth-Moon-Earth): EME komunikacija (Link na EN). Tehnika komunikacije odbijanjem radio signala od Mjeseca.
  • ERP (Effective Radiated Power): Efektivna izračena snaga. Umnožak snage dovedene na antenu i dobitka antene u odnosu na polurasni dipol.

docs.title: F
docs.text:
• FM (Frequency Modulation): Frekvencijska modulacija. Vrsta modulacije gdje se informacija prenosi promjenom frekvencije nosioca.
  • FT8: FT8 (Link na EN). Popularan digitalni način rada dizajniran za komunikaciju slabim signalima.

docs.title: G
docs.text:
• GND (Ground): Uzemljenje. Električni spoj s tlom radi sigurnosti i referentnog potencijala.
  • GP (Ground Plane): Monopol antena. Vertikalna antena (monopol) koja koristi "umjetnu zemlju" od radijala kako bi simulirala idealnu vodljivu ravninu.

docs.title: H
docs.text:
• HF (High Frequency): Kratki val. Radiofrekvencijski opseg od 3 do 30 MHz.
  • HT (Handheld Transceiver): Walkie-talkie. Mala, prijenosna radio stanica s baterijom i antenom u jednom kućištu.

docs.title: I
docs.text:
• IARU: IARU (Link na EN). Međunarodna radioamaterska unija, savez nacionalnih udruga.
  • ITU: Međunarodna telekomunikacijska unija. Agencija UN-a za informacijske i komunikacijske tehnologije.

docs.title: L
docs.text:
• LDS (Long Delayed Echo): LDE (Link na EN). Fenomen gdje se radio signal vraća pošiljatelju nakon nekoliko sekundi kašnjenja.
  • LSB (Lower Sideband): Jednobočna modulacija. Donji bočni pojas amplitudne modulacije.

docs.title: M
docs.text: • MUF (Maximum Usable Frequency): MUF (Link na EN). Najviša frekvencija koja se može koristiti za komunikaciju između dvije točke putem refleksije od ionosfere.

docs.title: O
docs.text: • OM (Old Man): Žargonski izraz za radioamatera (muškog), bez obzira na dob. Prijateljsko oslovljavanje.

docs.title: P
docs.text:
• PA (Power Amplifier): Pojačalo snage. Uređaj koji povećava snagu radio signala prije odašiljanja.
  • PEP (Peak Envelope Power): Vršna snaga ovojnice (Link na EN). Standardna mjera snage za SSB odašiljače.
  • PTT (Push To Talk): PTT (Link na EN). Tipka ili prekidač koji prebacuje uređaj s prijema na predaju.

docs.title: Q
docs.text: (Vidi Q-kodovi za detaljniji popis) - Q-kod: Q-kod. Standardizirana zbirka tročlanih kodova za komunikaciju.

docs.title: R
docs.text:
• RIT (Receiver Incremental Tuning): Funkcija koja omogućuje finu promjenu frekvencije prijema bez utjecaja na frekvenciju odašiljanja (Clarifier).
  • RST: RST kod (Link na EN). Sustav za ocjenjivanje kvalitete signala (Čitljivost, Snaga, Ton).
  • RTTY (Radioteletype): Radioteleprinter. Telekomunikacijski sustav za prijenos teksta putem radija.

docs.title: S
docs.text:
• SWR (Standing Wave Ratio): Omjer stojnih valova. Mjera prilagođenosti impedancije antene i odašiljača.
  • SSB (Single Sideband): Jednobočna modulacija. Efikasan način prijenosa glasa korištenjem samo jednog bočnog pojasa.
  • Squelch: Squelch (Link na EN). Sklop koji prigušuje šum iz zvučnika kada nema korisnog signala.

docs.title: T
docs.text:
• TVI (Television Interference): Smetnje koje radio odašiljač uzrokuje na televizijskom prijemu.
  • TX: Kratica za odašiljač (Transmitter) ili čin odašiljanja.

docs.title: U
docs.text:
• UHF (Ultra High Frequency): UHF. Radiofrekvencijski opseg od 300 MHz do 3 GHz.
  • USB (Upper Sideband): Jednobočna modulacija. Gornji bočni pojas amplitudne modulacije.
  • UTC: Koordinirano univerzalno vrijeme. Vremenski standard koji se koristi u radioamaterizmu.

docs.title: V
docs.text:
• VFO (Variable Frequency Oscillator): Oscilator promjenjive frekvencije (Link na EN). Dio radija koji omogućuje kontinuirano mijenjanje frekvencije.
  • VHF (Very High Frequency): VHF. Radiofrekvencijski opseg od 30 do 300 MHz.
  • VOX (Voice Operated Exchange): VOX (Link na EN). Sustav koji automatski uključuje odašiljač kada detektira glas.

docs.title: W
docs.text:
• WARC: WARC opsezi (Link na EN). Radioamaterski opsezi dodijeljeni 1979. godine (12m, 17m, 30m).
  • WPM (Words Per Minute): Riječi u minuti (Link na EN). Mjerna jedinica za brzinu slanja/primanja telegrafije.

docs.title: X
docs.text: • XYL (Ex-Young Lady): Žargonski izraz za suprugu radioamatera.

docs.title: Y
docs.text: • YL (Young Lady): Žargonski izraz za ženu radioamatera ili operatoricu.

docs.title: Z
docs.text: • Z (Zulu Time): Zulu vrijeme (Link na EN). Vojna/avijatičarska oznaka za UTC.

docs.title: Tehnika
docs.text: Tehnički aspekt je srž radioamaterizma. Ovdje obrađujemo sve od osnova elektronike do naprednih komunikacijskih sustava.

docs.title: Sadržaj
docs.text:
• Osnove elektronike: Otpornici, kondenzatori, zavojnice, poluvodiči.
  • Antene i vodovi: Dipoli, Yagi, vertikalke, koaksijalni kabeli.
  • Primopredajnici i oprema: Kako odabrati uređaj, dodatna oprema.
  • Sigurnost u radu: Uzemljenje, zaštita od groma, RF zračenje.
  • Samogradnja (DIY): Projekti za samostalnu izradu.
  • Hamnet: High Speed Multimedia mreža.

docs.title: Antene i vodovi
docs.text: Antena je najvažniji dio svake radio stanice. Loša antena na skupom uređaju radi lošije nego dobra antena na jeftinom uređaju.

docs.title: Dipol
docs.text: Najjednostavnija i vrlo efikasna antena. - Sastoji se od dvije žice ukupne duljine $\lambda/2$ (pola valne duljine). - Primjer za 20m (14 MHz): Ukupna duljina oko 10m.

docs.title: Yagi-Uda (Beam)
docs.text: Usmjerena antena koja pojačava signal u jednom smjeru. - Sastoji se od dipola (zračeći element), reflektora i direktora. - Koristi se za DX rad jer "fokusira" energiju.

docs.title: Vertikalka (Ground Plane)
docs.text: Omnidirekcijska antena (zrači u svim smjerovima). - Dobra za lokalne veze (VHF/UHF) i DX na nižim frekvencijama ako ima dobro uzemljenje.

docs.title: Koaksijalni kabel
docs.text: Najčešće korišten vod. - RG-58: Tanak, za kraće relacije i manje snage. - RG-213: Deblji, manji gubici, za veće snage. - Impedancija: Standard je 50 $\Omega$.

docs.title: SWR (Standing Wave Ratio)
docs.text: Omjer stojnih valova. Mjera prilagođenosti antene i voda. - 1:1: Savršeno. - do 1.5:1: Odlično. - preko 2:1: Potrebno ugađanje ili korištenje tunera.

docs.title: Osnove elektronike
docs.text: Razumijevanje elektronike je temelj za svakog radioamatera.

docs.title: Otpornik (Resistor)
docs.text: Ograničava tok električne struje. - Jedinica: Ohm ($\Omega$) - Oznaka: R - Primjena: Prilagodba napona, ograničavanje struje LED dioda.

docs.title: Kondenzator (Capacitor)
docs.text: Pohranjuje električnu energiju u električnom polju. - Jedinica: Farad (F) - najčešće $\mu F$, $nF$, $pF$. - Oznaka: C - Primjena: Filtriranje napona, titrajni krugovi, blokiranje istosmjerne struje.

docs.title: Zavojnica (Inductor)
docs.text: Pohranjuje energiju u magnetskom polju. - Jedinica: Henry (H) - najčešće $\mu H$, $mH$. - Oznaka: L - Primjena: Titrajni krugovi, prigušnice, transformatori.

docs.title: Poluvodiči
docs.text:
• Dioda: Propušta struju samo u jednom smjeru (ispravljači).
  • Tranzistor: Pojačava signal ili radi kao sklopka (BJT, FET). Temelj svih modernih uređaja.

docs.title: Ohmov zakon
docs.text: Temeljni zakon elektrotehnike: $$ I = \frac{U}{R} $$ Gdje je: - $I$ = Struja (Amper) - $U$ = Napon (Volt) - $R$ = Otpor (Ohm)

docs.title: Snaga
docs.text: $$ P = U \cdot I $$ - $P$ = Snaga (Watt)

docs.title: Hamnet (High Speed Multimedia)
docs.text: Hamnet je brza radioamaterska mreža bazirana na IP protokolu, koja koristi modificiranu WiFi opremu na radioamaterskim frekvencijama.

docs.title: Uvod i infrastruktura
docs.text: Što je Hamnet, kako radi i koja se oprema koristi (Ubiquiti, Mikrotik).

docs.title: Njemačka iskustva i rješenja (DAeC)
docs.text: Njemačka ima jednu od najrazvijenijih Hamnet mreža na svijetu. Ovdje ćemo prenijeti njihova iskustva i najbolje prakse.

docs.title: Primjena
docs.text:
• Povezivanje repetitora
  • Video nadzor
  • VoIP telefonija
  • Pristup serverima i servisima unutar mreže

docs.title: Sigurnost u radu
docs.text: Sigurnost je na prvom mjestu! Radioamateri rade s visokim naponima i elektromagnetskim zračenjem.

docs.title: Električna sigurnost
docs.text:
• Uzemljenje: Sve metalne dijelove opreme treba uzemljiti na zajedničku točku.
  • Osigurači: Koristite odgovarajuće osigurače na napajanju.
  • Antene: Nikada ne dirajte antenu dok odašiljete! Na krajevima dipola mogu se stvoriti naponi od nekoliko tisuća volti.

docs.title: Zaštita od groma
docs.text:
• Odvajanje: Najbolja zaštita je fizičko odvajanje antene od uređaja kada se ne koristi (posebno ljeti).
  • Odvodnici prenapona: Pomažu kod statičkog elektriciteta, ali ne jamče zaštitu od direktnog udara.

docs.title: RF Zračenje (PEM)
docs.text:
• Sigurne udaljenosti: Držite antene dalje od ljudi.
  • Neionizirajuće zračenje: Radio valovi ne oštećuju DNK kao rendgenske zrake, ali mogu izazvati zagrijavanje tkiva pri velikim snagama.
  • Oči: Posebno su osjetljive na zagrijavanje (UHF/mikrovalovi).

docs.title: Primopredajnici i oprema
docs.text: Radio uređaj (primopredajnik ili transceiver) je srce vaše stanice.

docs.title: Ručni uređaji (Handheld / HT)
docs.text:
• Opis: Mali, prijenosni uređaji s baterijom i antenom.
  • Frekvencije: Najčešće VHF (2m) i UHF (70cm).
  • Snaga: Obično do 5W.
  • Primjena: Lokalne veze, repetitori, rad na terenu.

docs.title: Mobilni uređaji
docs.text:
• Opis: Dizajnirani za ugradnju u vozila, ali često se koriste i u kući.
  • Frekvencije: VHF/UHF, ponekad i HF.
  • Snaga: 25W - 50W.
  • Primjena: Mobilni rad, bazne stanice za lokalne veze.

docs.title: Bazni uređaji (HF Transceivers)
docs.text:
• Opis: Veći uređaji za stacionarni rad.
  • Frekvencije: HF (kratki val), često i 6m.
  • Snaga: Standardno 100W.
  • Primjena: DX rad, natjecanja, digitalni modovi.

docs.title: SDR (Software Defined Radio)
docs.text:
• Opis: Radio gdje se većina obrade signala vrši softverski.
  • Prednosti: Vizualni prikaz spektra (vodopad), odlični filteri.
  • Primjeri: Icom IC-7300, FlexRadio, SunSDR.

docs.title: Dodatna oprema
docs.text:
• Napajanje: Pretvara 230V AC u 13.8V DC.
  • SWR Metar: Mjeri prilagođenost antene.
  • Antenski Tuner (ATU): Prilagođava impedanciju antene uređaju.
  • Mikrofon / Tipkalo: Za glasovni ili telegrafski rad.

docs.title: Welcome to the Ham Radio Handbook
docs.text: This is the central hub for all information regarding amateur radio. Whether you are a beginner looking to pass the exam or an experienced operator seeking specific technical details, you will find everything you need here.

docs.title: What is Amateur Radio?
docs.text: Amateur radio (ham radio) is a popular hobby and service that brings people, electronics, and communication together. People use ham radio to talk across town, around the world, or even into space, all without the Internet or cell phones.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
• Regulations & Licensing: How to become a ham, laws, and rules.
  • Technical: Electronics, antennas, and equipment.
  • Operating: How to make a contact, modes, and procedures.
  • CB Radio: Citizens Band.
  • Activities: Contesting, SOTA, DXing.
  • Emergency Comms: Ham radio in emergencies.
  • Community: Clubs and associations.
  • Resources: Links and tools.

News

This site is under construction! Stay tuned for new content.

docs.title: Activities
docs.text: Amateur radio offers a multitude of activities.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
• Contesting: Competing for the highest number of contacts.
  • DXing: Contacts with distant and rare countries.
  • Portable Operations: SOTA (Summits), POTA (Parks), IOTA (Islands).
  • Satellites: Communication via amateur satellites.
  • ARDF: Amateur Radio Direction Finding ("Fox hunting").

docs.title: Amateur Radio Direction Finding (ARDF)
docs.text: Also known as "Fox Hunting".

docs.title: What is ARDF?
docs.text: A technical-sports discipline where competitors use a receiver and antenna to find hidden transmitters ("foxes") in nature.

docs.title: Categories
docs.text:
• 3.5 MHz (80m): Classic discipline. Receivers are simpler.
  • 144 MHz (2m): More demanding due to signal reflections.

docs.title: Equipment
docs.text:
• Receiver: Specially designed for ARDF, with a directional antenna (ferrite for 80m, Yagi/HB9CV for 2m).
  • Compass and Map: For orientation in nature.

ARDF is a great way to learn about wave propagation and enjoy the outdoors. The Croatian national team is one of the most successful in the world!

docs.title: Contesting
docs.text: Amateur radio contests are the "sporting" part of the hobby. The goal is to make as many contacts as possible within a given time.

docs.title: How does it work?
docs.text:
• Duration: From a few hours to 48 hours.
  • Exchange: Instead of long conversations, only a report (59) and a serial number (or zone, locator) are exchanged.
  • Categories: Single Operator, Multi Operator, Low Power (QRP), etc.

docs.title: Popular Contests
docs.text:
• CQ WW DX: The world's largest contest (October SSB, November CW).
  • 9A CW Contest: Croatian contest (December).
  • IOTA Contest: Island contacts (July).

docs.title: Equipment and Software
docs.text:
• Serious results require good antennas and amplifiers.
  • Specialized software (N1MM, DXLog) is used, connected to the radio to automatically send CW or voice messages.

docs.title: DXing (Long Distance)
docs.text: DXing is the hunt for distant and rare countries (entities).

docs.title: What is DX?
docs.text:
• On Shortwave (HF), DX is usually a contact with another continent.
  • On VHF/UHF, DX can be a contact of a few hundred kilometers.

docs.title: DXCC List
docs.text: The ARRL maintains a list of "DXCC entities". These are not always countries; they can be remote islands (e.g., Hawaii, Antarctica). There are currently about 340 of them. The goal of every DXer is to confirm contacts with all 340 entities.

docs.title: How to catch DX?
docs.text:
1. Listening: 90% of DXing is listening.
  2. DX Cluster: Websites where others post what they hear (e.g., DX Summit).
  3. Pile-up: A situation where hundreds of stations call one rare DX station. Skill and patience are needed to break through.
  4. Split Operation: The DX station listens on one frequency and transmits on another (e.g., "UP 5"). Never call on the DX station's frequency if they are working split!

docs.title: Portable Operations
docs.text: Going out into nature with a radio is one of the most beautiful parts of the hobby.

docs.title: SOTA (Summits On The Air)
docs.text: A program that encourages hams to operate from mountain summits. - Activator: Climbs the summit and makes contacts (must carry all equipment). - Chaser: Collects points by working activators. - SOTA Website

docs.title: POTA (Parks On The Air)
docs.text: Similar to SOTA, but operating from national parks and nature reserves. - More accessible as you can often drive close to the location. - POTA Website

docs.title: IOTA (Islands On The Air)
docs.text: Operating from islands. - Very popular, especially in summer. - Some islands are rare and sought after. - IOTA Website

docs.title: Portable Equipment
docs.text:
• Lightweight radios (QRP, e.g., Yaesu FT-818, Elecraft KX2).
  • Wire antennas (Dipole, End-fed) or verticals on a fishing pole.
  • Battery power (LiFePO4).

docs.title: Satellite Communications
docs.text: Radio amateurs have their own satellites in orbit!

docs.title: How does it work?
docs.text: Most amateur satellites are "flying repeaters". - Uplink: Frequency you transmit on (e.g., 435 MHz). - Downlink: Frequency you listen on (e.g., 145 MHz). - This is called Mode U/V (UHF up, VHF down).

docs.title: Doppler Effect
docs.text: Due to the high speed of the satellite, the frequency changes as the satellite approaches and departs. You must constantly correct the receive frequency.

docs.title: Equipment
docs.text:
• For FM satellites (e.g., ISS, SO-50), a handheld radio and a small directional antenna (Yagi) held in hand are sufficient.
  • For linear satellites (SSB/CW), better equipment and antennas with rotation (azimuth/elevation) are needed.

docs.title: ISS (International Space Station)
docs.text: Astronauts who are hams are often on the ISS. Sometimes they talk to schools (ARISS program) or send SSTV images.

docs.title: CB Radio (Citizens Band)
docs.text: Citizens Band (CB) is a public radio service that does not require a license exam, but still has its own rules.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
• Introduction to CB: History and purpose.
  • Regulations and Channels: Allowed frequencies (27 MHz) and power limits.
  • Equipment: Radios, antennas, and accessories.

docs.title: Channel Table
docs.text: CB uses 40 channels in the 27 MHz range. The most popular channels are Channel 9 (emergency) and Channel 19 (truckers/road).

docs.title: Regulations and Channels
docs.text: Although there is no exam, there are rules that must be followed.

docs.title: Allowed Parameters (Croatia / EU)
docs.text:
• Frequency Range: 26.965 MHz - 27.405 MHz.
  • Modulation: AM, FM, SSB (LSB/USB).
  • Power: 4W (AM/FM), 12W (SSB).

docs.title: Channel Table
docs.text:
Channel Frequency (MHz) Usage 1 26.965 9 27.065 Emergency 19 27.185 Road / Truckers 20 27.205 30 27.305 40 27.405

Note: There are also "alpha channels" which are skipped in the standard layout.

docs.title: CB Equipment
docs.text: CB equipment is simpler and cheaper than amateur radio gear.

docs.title: Radios
docs.text:
• Mobile: Most common. Installed in cars or used as base stations with a power supply. (e.g., President, Midland, Albrecht).
  • Handheld: Shorter range, but practical.

docs.title: Antennas
docs.text: The key to range on 27 MHz (11m wavelength). - Mobile Antennas: Shortened with a coil. The longer, the better (from 1m to 2m). Often magnet-mounted. - Base Antennas: Large verticals (5-7 meters). Allow ranges of 20-50 km locally, and hundreds of km when propagation conditions are good (DX).

docs.title: SWR
docs.text: As with hams, the antenna must be tuned (SWR < 1.5). Most CB antennas have a screw for length adjustment.

docs.title: Introduction to CB (Citizens Band)
docs.text: CB (Citizens Band) is "radio for the people". Unlike amateur radio, it does not require passing an exam.

docs.title: History
docs.text: Originating in the USA in the 1940s, CB boomed in the 1970s ("Convoy", "Smokey and the Bandit"). In Europe and Croatia, it is popular among truck drivers, off-road enthusiasts, and people who want free short-distance communication.

docs.title: Difference from Amateur Radio
docs.text:
• No Exam: Anyone can buy a radio and use it.
  • Limited Power: Usually 4W (AM/FM) or 12W (SSB).
  • Fixed Channels: Uses 40 channels, no free frequency tuning (VFO).
  • Purpose: Personal and business communication, hobby.

docs.title: Who uses CB today?
docs.text:
• Truck Drivers: Traffic information (Channel 19).
  • Off-road Clubs: Convoy communication.
  • Preppers: Disaster communication.

docs.title: Community
docs.text: Amateur radio is a social hobby.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
• Associations: National amateur radio societies.
  • Radio Clubs: Find a club near you.
  • YOTA: Youngsters On The Air.

docs.title: Associations and Organizations
docs.text: Radio amateurs are organized at national and international levels.

docs.title: HRS (Croatian Amateur Radio Association)
docs.text: The umbrella organization of radio amateurs in the Republic of Croatia. - Membership: You become a member through a radio club or directly. - QSL Bureau: HRS runs the national QSL bureau for card exchange. - Exams: Organizes license exams. - Contests: Organizes 9A CW, 9A Activity, and other contests. - HRS Website

docs.title: IARU (International Amateur Radio Union)
docs.text: The world organization representing radio amateurs before the ITU. - Croatia is a member of IARU Region 1. - IARU Website

docs.title: Radio Clubs
docs.text: The radio club is the basic cell of amateur radio. It is a place where enthusiasts gather, exchange experiences, and use common equipment.

docs.title: Why join?
docs.text:
• Equipment: Clubs often have top-notch radios and antennas that an individual can hardly afford.
  • Education: Older members (mentors) pass on knowledge to new ones.
  • Socializing: Amateur radio is a social hobby.

docs.title: How to find a club?
docs.text:
The HRS website has a list of all active radio clubs in Croatia. - List of Radio Clubs

Visit a club in your city, meet the people, and see what it looks like live!

docs.title: YOTA (Youngsters On The Air)
docs.text: YOTA is an international initiative of IARU Region 1 aimed at attracting and retaining young people in amateur radio.

docs.title: Activities
docs.text:
• YOTA Summer Camps: Every year in a different country, gathering hundreds of young hams.
  • YOTA Month (December): Special call signs with the YOTA suffix are active all month. The goal is to make contact with them.
  • YOTA Contest: A contest tailored for young people.

docs.title: YOTA Croatia
docs.text:
Croatia is very active in the YOTA program. Young Croatian hams regularly participate in camps and achieve top results in contests.

If you are under 26, this is the program for you!

docs.title: Emergency Communications (EmComm)
docs.text: Radio amateurs are often the last line of defense when all other communication systems fail.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
• EmComm Networks: Emergency communication networks.
  • Procedures: How to behave in emergencies.
  • Winlink: Sending email via radio.

docs.title: Emergency Procedures
docs.text: When a disaster strikes, discipline is key.

docs.title: Golden Rules
docs.text:
1. Listen: Do not transmit unless called or you have urgent information.
  2. Short and Clear: Use the phonetic alphabet. Avoid jargon.
  3. Write it down: All messages must be written down (time, sender, content).

docs.title: Message Types
docs.text:
• Mayday / SOS: Immediate danger to life. Absolute priority.
  • Pan-Pan: Urgent situation, but no immediate danger to life.
  • Securite: Safety warning (e.g., weather).

docs.title: IARU Emergency Message
docs.text: A standardized format for sending messages ensuring nothing is lost in transmission.

docs.title: RMZO (Emergency Radio Network)
docs.text: RMZO is a system within the Croatian Amateur Radio Association that is activated in case of disasters.

docs.title: Organization
docs.text:
• National Level: Coordinated by HRS in cooperation with the Civil Protection Directorate.
  • Local Level: Radio clubs and individuals who make themselves available to local headquarters.

docs.title: Activation
docs.text: RMZO is activated at the call of competent authorities (112) or self-initiated in case of obvious telecommunication failure.

docs.title: Frequencies
docs.text:
• 3.675 MHz (80m): Main frequency for national coordination.
  • 145.500 MHz (2m): Local simplex frequency.
  • Repeaters: Local repeaters with independent power supply are used.

docs.title: Winlink
docs.text: Winlink is a global system for sending email via radio. It is crucial in EmComm as it allows sending detailed reports, lists, and images when the internet is down.

docs.title: How does it work?
docs.text:
• User: Connects a computer to a radio (HF or VHF).
  • Gateway (RMS): A radio station connected to the internet that receives the message.
  • CMS: Central servers (cloud) that forward the mail to the regular internet.

docs.title: Advantages
docs.text:
• Works without local internet (via HF you connect to a gateway in another country).
  • Supports attachments (images, PDF).
  • Integrated with civil protection forms (ICS forms).

docs.title: Equipment
docs.text:
• Computer with software (Winlink Express).
  • Radio.
  • Modem (TNC) or software modem (VARA).

docs.title: Operating
docs.text: Here you will learn how to actually make contacts, which frequencies to use, and what rules of conduct apply on the air.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:

  • Modes: Detailed overview of analog and digital modes.
  • QSO Procedures: How to start and end a contact.
  • Q-Codes and Abbreviations: The language of hams.
  • Logbooks and QSL Cards: Confirming contacts.

docs.title: Logbooks and QSL Cards
docs.text: Every contact made should be logged. This is a legal requirement and part of the tradition.

docs.title: Logbook
docs.text: The logbook must contain: - Date and time (UTC). - Correspondent's call sign. - Frequency (or band). - Mode. - Report (RST).

docs.title: Paper vs. Electronic
docs.text: Today, most use computer programs (loggers) such as N1MM, DXKeeper, or Ham Radio Deluxe. They automatically record time and frequency (if connected to the radio).

docs.title: QSL Cards
docs.text: A QSL card is a written confirmation of a contact. It is the "final courtesy" of a ham. - Paper QSL: Sent directly by mail or (cheaper) via the national association's QSL bureau. - Electronic QSL: - LoTW (Logbook of The World): ARRL system. Officially recognized for awards (DXCC). - eQSL: Popular, but less "official". - ClubLog: Excellent for analysis and OQRS (Online QSL Request System).

docs.title: Modes
docs.text: Radio amateurs use various methods to transmit information. Modes are divided into analog and digital, and within those, into voice and data.

docs.title: Voice
docs.text:
• SSB (Single Sideband): Most popular mode for DX (long-distance) on HF.
  • FM (Frequency Modulation): Standard for local contacts on VHF/UHF.
  • AM (Amplitude Modulation): Historic mode, less used today.

docs.title: Data
docs.text:
• CW (Continuous Wave): Telegraphy, the most efficient mode for weak signals.
  • SSTV (Slow Scan TV): Transmission of static images.

docs.title: Voice
docs.text:
• DMR (Digital Mobile Radio): Commercial standard adapted for hams.
  • D-Star: First digital mode developed specifically for hams (Icom).
  • C4FM (System Fusion): Yaesu standard.

docs.title: Data
docs.text:
• FT8 / FT4: Most popular weak-signal modes today.
  • RTTY (Radioteletype): Classic for contesting.
  • PSK31: Popular "chat" mode.
  • APRS: Position reporting and short messaging system.
  • Packet Radio: Packet data transmission (AX.25).

docs.title: QSO Procedures
docs.text: Making a contact has its rules to ensure efficient and understandable communication.

docs.title: Basic Terms
docs.text:
• CQ: General call ("Calling Any Station").
  • DE: From (used in CW or digital modes).
  • K: Over.
  • 73: Best Regards.

docs.title: Example Contact (SSB)
docs.text:
1. Call: "CQ CQ CQ, this is 9A1AA, 9A1AA calling and listening."
  2. Reply: "9A1AA, this is DL1BBB."
  3. Report: "DL1BBB, good day. Your signal is 59 (five-nine), name is Ivan, locator JN75. 9A1AA."
  4. Confirmation: "9A1AA, thanks Ivan. Your signal is also 59, my name is Hans. 73!"
  5. End: "Thanks Hans, 73 and hope to hear you again. DL1BBB de 9A1AA."

docs.title: RST System
docs.text:
The report consists of 3 digits (for CW) or 2 (for SSB): - R (Readability): 1-5. - S (Signal Strength): 1-9. - T (Tone): 1-9 (CW only).

Example: 599 (Perfect signal on CW).

docs.title: Q-Codes
docs.text: Q-codes are standardized three-letter codes starting with the letter Q. Originally developed for telegraphy to speed up communication, they are now also used in voice modes.

docs.title: Frequently Used Q-Codes
docs.text: Code Question Answer / Advice QRA What is the name of your station? The name of my station is... QRG What is my exact frequency? Your exact frequency is ... kHz. QRL Are you busy? I am busy (please do not interfere). QRM Is my transmission being interfered with? You are being interfered with (1-5). QRN Are you troubled by static? I am troubled by static (1-5). QRO Shall I increase power? Increase power. QRP Shall I decrease power? Decrease power. QRT Shall I stop sending? Stop sending. QRZ Who is calling me? You are being called by... (on ... kHz). QSB Are my signals fading? Your signals are fading. QSL Can you acknowledge receipt? I am acknowledging receipt. QSO Can you communicate with...? I can communicate with... QSY Shall I change to transmission on another frequency? Change to transmission on ... kHz. QTH What is your position in latitude and longitude (or by any other indication)? My position is...

docs.title: All Q-Codes (Amateur Radio)
docs.text: Code Meaning QRA Name of station / Address QRB Distance between stations QRC Who pays the charges (commercial, rare in ham) QRD Where are you bound and where are you from? QRE Estimated time of arrival? QRF Are you returning? QRG Exact frequency QRH Does my frequency vary? QRI Tone of transmission (T in RST) QRJ Are you receiving me badly? QRK Readability of signals (R in RST) QRL Frequency is busy QRM Interference from other stations QRN Atmospheric interference (static) QRO High power QRP Low power QRQ Send faster QRR Are you ready for automatic operation? QRRS Land SOS (rarely used) QRS Send slower QRT Stop sending / Shutting down QRU Have you anything for me? QRV I am ready QRW Shall I inform...? QRX Wait a moment QRY What is my turn? QRZ Who is calling me? QSA Signal strength (S in RST) QSB Fading QSD Keying is defective QSK Can you hear me between your signals (Break-in)? QSL Acknowledge receipt (card) QSM Shall I repeat the last message? QSN Did you hear me? QSO Contact QSP Will you relay to...? QSQ Have you a doctor? QSR Shall I repeat the call? QSS What working frequency will you use? QST General call to all amateurs (message) QSU Shall I send or reply on this frequency? QSV Shall I send a series of V's? QSW Will you send on this frequency? QSX Will you listen to...? QSY Change frequency QSZ Shall I send each word twice? QTA Shall I cancel message? QTB Do you agree with my counting of words? QTC How many messages have you to send? QTH Location (City, Locator) QTR Exact time

docs.title: Call Signs
docs.text: A call sign is a unique identifier for an amateur radio station.

docs.title: Structure (Croatia)
docs.text:
Croatian call signs consist of three parts:

  1. Prefix: 9A (indicates Croatia).
  2. Number: 1 - 9 (historically indicated region, today mostly arbitrary but often follows: 1-Zagreb, 2-Dalmatia, 3-Istria/Littoral, 4-Slavonia...). 0 is used for special signs.
  3. Suffix: 1, 2, or 3 letters.
    • 1 letter: Clubs with long tradition or special signs (e.g., 9A1A).
    • 2 letters: Standard personal signs (e.g., 9A2AA) or clubs.
    • 3 letters: Standard personal signs (e.g., 9A3AAA).

docs.title: Types of Call Signs
docs.text:
• Personal Call Signs: Assigned to individuals after passing the exam.
  • Club Call Signs: Assigned to radio clubs.
  • Special Call Signs: For contests, anniversaries, or expeditions (e.g., 9A80Z, 9A0HQ).

docs.title: Identification
docs.text: During operation, a ham must regularly transmit their call sign (at the start, end, and every 10-15 minutes during contact). When operating from another country (CEPT), place that country's prefix before your call sign (e.g., S5/9A1AA if in Slovenia). When operating portable/mobile, add the suffix /P (portable), /M (mobile), or /MM (maritime mobile).

docs.title: Croatian Regulations
docs.text: Amateur radio in Croatia is regulated by a series of laws and ordinances.

docs.title: 1. Electronic Communications Act
docs.text: The fundamental law governing the use of the radio frequency spectrum.

docs.title: 2. Ordinance on Amateur Radio Communications
docs.text: This is the "bible" for hams in Croatia. It defines: - License types and classes. - Frequency bands and power limits. - Technical conditions for stations. - Call sign formation rules.

docs.title: 3. National Table of Frequency Allocations
docs.text: The document that determines the purpose of each part of the spectrum in Croatia.

docs.title: Competent Authorities
docs.text:
• HAKOM (Croatian Regulatory Authority for Network Industries): Issues licenses, allocates call signs, and monitors operation.
    • Web: www.hakom.hr
  • HRS (Croatian Amateur Radio Association): The national association representing the interests of hams, organizing exams, and managing the QSL bureau.
    • Web: www.hamradio.hr

docs.title: How to Become a Ham?
docs.text: The path to an amateur radio license involves passing an examination. In Croatia, there are two classes of amateur radio operators: P (Entry Level) and A (Advanced).

docs.title: Class P (Entry Level)
docs.text: This is the entry point into the world of amateur radio. - Privileges: Operation on all amateur frequency bands, but with limited power (up to 100W on HF, up to 50W on VHF/UHF). - Exam: Simpler, focused on the basics of regulations, technical topics, and operating procedures. - Recommendation: Ideal for beginners who want to get on the air quickly.

docs.title: Class A (Advanced)
docs.text: Full amateur radio privileges. - Privileges: Operation with maximum legal power (up to 1.5 kW in some cases) and access to all international privileges (CEPT HAREC). - Exam: More comprehensive, includes deeper knowledge of electronics and radio theory. - Recommendation: For those who want to utilize the full potential of the hobby.

docs.title: Examination Process
docs.text:
1. Preparation:
    • Find the nearest radio club (Club List). Clubs often organize courses.
    • Download manuals and question pools from the HRS website.
  2. Application:
    • Exams are organized in radio clubs or directly at the HRS.
  3. The Exam:
    • Consists of a written part (test). There is no longer a practical part (Morse code is not mandatory).

docs.title: After the Exam
docs.text:
After successfully passing the exam, you receive an Examination Certificate. With this, you apply to HAKOM for a License to use RF spectrum and the allocation of a call sign.

Tip

The best way to learn is with a mentor in a radio club. Practical experience is invaluable!

docs.title: International Regulations
docs.text: Amateur radio is a global hobby, so international coordination is crucial.

docs.title: ITU (International Telecommunication Union)
docs.text: The UN agency that coordinates the use of the radio frequency spectrum globally. - Radio Regulations (RR): International regulations defining the amateur service.

docs.title: IARU (International Amateur Radio Union)
docs.text: Represents the interests of radio amateurs before the ITU. - Divided into 3 regions: 1. Region 1: Europe, Africa, Middle East, Northern Asia. 2. Region 2: The Americas. 3. Region 3: Rest of Asia, Australia, Oceania.

docs.title: CEPT (European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations)
docs.text: European organization that harmonizes regulations. - Recommendation T/R 61-01: Allows hams with a CEPT license (Class A in Croatia) to operate in other signatory countries without additional bureaucracy (up to 3 months). - Recommendation T/R 61-02: Harmonized Amateur Radio Examination Certificate (HAREC).

docs.title: What does this mean for you?
docs.text: If you pass Class A in Croatia, your license is recognized in most European countries (and many others). You can travel and operate your station using the prefix of the country you are visiting (e.g., DL/9A1AA).

docs.title: Ham Radio Dictionary (Abbreviations)
docs.text:
Here you can find explanations of the most common abbreviations used by radio amateurs.

A | B | C | D | E | F | G | H | I | L | M | O | P | Q | R | S | T | U | V | W | X | Y | Z

docs.title: A
docs.text:
• AF (Audio Frequency): Audio frequency. The frequency range audible to the human ear (approx. 20 Hz to 20 kHz).
  • AGC (Automatic Gain Control): Automatic gain control. A circuit that maintains a constant output level despite variations in input signal strength.
  • ALC (Automatic Level Control): A circuit in a transmitter that prevents overmodulation or overdriving the power amplifier.
  • AM (Amplitude Modulation): Amplitude modulation. A modulation technique where information is encoded by varying the amplitude of the carrier wave.
  • APRS (Automatic Packet Reporting System): APRS. A system for real-time digital communications of information of immediate value (position, messages, telemetry).

docs.title: B
docs.text:
• BCI (Broadcast Interference): Interference caused by broadcast stations (e.g., FM radio or TV).
  • BFO (Beat Frequency Oscillator): Beat frequency oscillator. An oscillator in a receiver used to create an audible tone for CW and SSB reception.
  • BK (Break-in): QSK. The ability to hear the other station between your own Morse code characters (Full Break-in).

docs.title: C
docs.text:
• CEPT: CEPT. European body that regulates the mutual recognition of amateur radio licenses.
  • CQ: CQ (call). A general call to all stations ("Calling any station").
  • CW (Continuous Wave): Continuous wave. A method of communication by keying a carrier on and off (Morse code).

docs.title: D
docs.text:
• dB (Decibel): Decibel. A logarithmic unit used to express the ratio of two values (e.g., power or voltage).
  • Dipole: Dipole antenna. The simplest type of antenna, consisting of two conductive elements, typically half a wavelength long in total.
  • Dummy Load: Dummy load. A resistor (usually 50 ohms) connected to a transmitter instead of an antenna for testing purposes without radiating.
  • DX (Distance): DXing. Abbreviation for distance or contact with a distant/rare station.

docs.title: E
docs.text:
• EME (Earth-Moon-Earth): EME communication. A technique relying on the reflection of radio signals from the Moon.
  • ERP (Effective Radiated Power): Effective radiated power. The product of the power supplied to the antenna and its gain relative to a half-wave dipole.

docs.title: F
docs.text:
• FM (Frequency Modulation): Frequency modulation. A modulation technique where information is encoded by varying the frequency of the carrier wave.
  • FT8: FT8. A popular digital mode designed for weak-signal communication.

docs.title: G
docs.text:
• GND (Ground): Ground (electricity). Electrical connection to the earth for safety and reference potential.
  • GP (Ground Plane): Monopole antenna. A vertical antenna (monopole) mounted over a ground plane (often radials) to simulate a perfect conductive surface.

docs.title: H
docs.text:
• HF (High Frequency): High frequency. The radio frequency range from 3 to 30 MHz (Shortwave).
  • HT (Handheld Transceiver): Walkie-talkie. A portable radio with battery and antenna in a single unit.

docs.title: I
docs.text:
• IARU: International Amateur Radio Union. An alliance of national amateur radio societies.
  • ITU: International Telecommunication Union. The UN agency for information and communication technologies.

docs.title: L
docs.text:
• LDS (Long Delayed Echo): Long delayed echo. A phenomenon where a radio signal returns to the sender after a significant delay.
  • LSB (Lower Sideband): Single-sideband modulation. The lower sideband of an AM signal.

docs.title: M
docs.text: • MUF (Maximum Usable Frequency): Maximum usable frequency. The highest frequency that can be used for communication between two points via ionospheric reflection.

docs.title: O
docs.text: • OM (Old Man): Slang for a male amateur radio operator, regardless of age. A friendly term.

docs.title: P
docs.text:
• PA (Power Amplifier): RF power amplifier. A device that increases the power of a radio signal before transmission.
  • PEP (Peak Envelope Power): Peak envelope power. The standard power measurement for SSB transmitters.
  • PTT (Push To Talk): Push-to-talk. A switch that switches the device from receive to transmit mode.

docs.title: Q
docs.text: (See Q-Codes for a detailed list) - Q-code: Q code. A standardized collection of three-letter codes.

docs.title: R
docs.text:
• RIT (Receiver Incremental Tuning): A control that allows fine-tuning of the receive frequency without affecting the transmit frequency.
  • RST: R-S-T system. A system for reporting signal quality (Readability, Strength, Tone).
  • RTTY (Radioteletype): Radioteletype. A telecommunications system for transmitting text via radio.

docs.title: S
docs.text:
• SWR (Standing Wave Ratio): Standing wave ratio. A measure of impedance matching between the antenna and transmitter.
  • SSB (Single Sideband): Single-sideband modulation. An efficient voice transmission method using only one sideband.
  • Squelch: Squelch. A circuit that suppresses the audio output of a receiver in the absence of a strong input signal.

docs.title: T
docs.text:
• TVI (Television Interference): Interference caused by a radio transmitter to television reception.
  • TX: Abbreviation for Transmitter or Transmitting.

docs.title: U
docs.text:
• UHF (Ultra High Frequency): Ultra high frequency. The radio frequency range from 300 MHz to 3 GHz.
  • USB (Upper Sideband): Single-sideband modulation. The upper sideband of an AM signal.
  • UTC: Coordinated Universal Time. The primary time standard by which the world regulates clocks and time.

docs.title: V
docs.text:
• VFO (Variable Frequency Oscillator): Variable-frequency oscillator. A component that allows continuous tuning of the frequency.
  • VHF (Very High Frequency): Very high frequency. The radio frequency range from 30 to 300 MHz.
  • VOX (Voice Operated Exchange): Voice-operated switch. A switch that operates when sound is detected.

docs.title: W
docs.text:
• WARC: WARC bands. Amateur radio bands allocated in 1979 (12m, 17m, 30m).
  • WPM (Words Per Minute): Words per minute. A measure of telegraphy speed.

docs.title: X
docs.text: • XYL (Ex-Young Lady): Slang for the wife of a ham.

docs.title: Y
docs.text: • YL (Young Lady): Slang for a female ham operator.

docs.title: Z
docs.text: • Z (Zulu Time): Zulu time. Military/Aviation designator for UTC.

docs.title: Technical
docs.text: The technical aspect is the core of amateur radio. Here we cover everything from the basics of electronics to advanced communication systems.

docs.title: Content
docs.text:
• Basics of Electronics: Resistors, capacitors, inductors, semiconductors.
  • Antennas and Feedlines: Dipoles, Yagis, verticals, coaxial cables.
  • Transceivers and Equipment: How to choose a radio, accessories.
  • Safety: Grounding, lightning protection, RF exposure.
  • Homebrew (DIY): Projects for self-construction.
  • Hamnet: High Speed Multimedia network.

docs.title: Antennas and Feedlines
docs.text: The antenna is the most important part of any radio station. A bad antenna on an expensive radio performs worse than a good antenna on a cheap radio.

docs.title: Dipole
docs.text: The simplest and very efficient antenna. - Consists of two wires with a total length of $\lambda/2$ (half wavelength). - Example for 20m (14 MHz): Total length about 10m.

docs.title: Yagi-Uda (Beam)
docs.text: Directional antenna that amplifies the signal in one direction. - Consists of a dipole (driven element), reflector, and directors. - Used for DX work as it "focuses" energy.

docs.title: Vertical (Ground Plane)
docs.text: Omnidirectional antenna (radiates in all directions). - Good for local contacts (VHF/UHF) and DX on lower frequencies if it has a good ground system.

docs.title: Coaxial Cable
docs.text: The most commonly used feedline. - RG-58: Thin, for shorter runs and lower power. - RG-213: Thicker, lower loss, for higher power. - Impedance: Standard is 50 $\Omega$.

docs.title: SWR (Standing Wave Ratio)
docs.text: Measure of impedance matching between antenna and feedline. - 1:1: Perfect. - up to 1.5:1: Excellent. - over 2:1: Tuning required or use of a tuner.

docs.title: Electronics Basics
docs.text: Understanding electronics is fundamental for every radio amateur.

docs.title: Resistor
docs.text: Limits the flow of electric current. - Unit: Ohm ($\Omega$) - Symbol: R - Usage: Voltage adjustment, current limiting for LEDs.

docs.title: Capacitor
docs.text: Stores electrical energy in an electric field. - Unit: Farad (F) - usually $\mu F$, $nF$, $pF$. - Symbol: C - Usage: Voltage filtering, resonant circuits, blocking DC current.

docs.title: Inductor
docs.text: Stores energy in a magnetic field. - Unit: Henry (H) - usually $\mu H$, $mH$. - Symbol: L - Usage: Resonant circuits, chokes, transformers.

docs.title: Semiconductors
docs.text:
• Diode: Allows current to flow in only one direction (rectifiers).
  • Transistor: Amplifies signals or acts as a switch (BJT, FET). The foundation of all modern devices.

docs.title: Ohm's Law
docs.text: The fundamental law of electrical engineering: $$ I = \frac{U}{R} $$ Where: - $I$ = Current (Ampere) - $U$ = Voltage (Volt) - $R$ = Resistance (Ohm)

docs.title: Power
docs.text: $$ P = U \cdot I $$ - $P$ = Power (Watt)

docs.title: Hamnet (High Speed Multimedia)
docs.text: Hamnet is a high-speed amateur radio network based on the IP protocol, using modified WiFi equipment on amateur radio frequencies.

docs.title: Intro & Infrastructure
docs.text: What is Hamnet, how it works, and what equipment is used (Ubiquiti, Mikrotik).

docs.title: German Hamnet (DAeC)
docs.text: Germany has one of the most developed Hamnet networks in the world. Here we will share their experiences and best practices.

docs.title: Applications
docs.text:
• Repeater linking
  • Video surveillance
  • VoIP telephony
  • Access to servers and services within the network

docs.title: Safety
docs.text: Safety comes first! Radio amateurs work with high voltages and electromagnetic radiation.

docs.title: Electrical Safety
docs.text:
• Grounding: All metal parts of equipment should be grounded to a common point.
  • Fuses: Use appropriate fuses on power supplies.
  • Antennas: Never touch an antenna while transmitting! Voltages of several thousand volts can develop at the ends of a dipole.

docs.title: Lightning Protection
docs.text:
• Disconnecting: The best protection is physically disconnecting the antenna from the radio when not in use (especially in summer).
  • Surge Arrestors: Help with static electricity but do not guarantee protection against a direct hit.

docs.title: RF Exposure (EMF)
docs.text:
• Safe Distances: Keep antennas away from people.
  • Non-ionizing Radiation: Radio waves do not damage DNA like X-rays, but can cause tissue heating at high power.
  • Eyes: Particularly sensitive to heating (UHF/Microwaves).

docs.title: Transceivers and Equipment
docs.text: The radio (transceiver) is the heart of your station.

docs.title: Handheld (HT)
docs.text:
• Description: Small, portable radios with battery and antenna.
  • Frequencies: Mostly VHF (2m) and UHF (70cm).
  • Power: Usually up to 5W.
  • Usage: Local contacts, repeaters, field operations.

docs.title: Mobile Radios
docs.text:
• Description: Designed for vehicle installation, but often used at home.
  • Frequencies: VHF/UHF, sometimes HF.
  • Power: 25W - 50W.
  • Usage: Mobile operation, base stations for local contacts.

docs.title: Base Stations (HF Transceivers)
docs.text:
• Description: Larger radios for stationary operation.
  • Frequencies: HF (Shortwave), often 6m.
  • Power: Standard 100W.
  • Usage: DX work, contesting, digital modes.

docs.title: SDR (Software Defined Radio)
docs.text:
• Description: Radio where most signal processing is done in software.
  • Advantages: Visual spectrum display (waterfall), excellent filters.
  • Examples: Icom IC-7300, FlexRadio, SunSDR.

docs.title: Accessories
docs.text:
• Power Supply: Converts 230V AC to 13.8V DC.
  • SWR Meter: Measures antenna matching.
  • Antenna Tuner (ATU): Matches antenna impedance to the radio.
  • Microphone / Key: For voice or telegraphy operation.
